webTitle: Ladbrokes: the helpless victim of a reckless chancellor? Hardly ...

fields.standfirst: Whatever one's view of the machines, a cash-strapped chancellor is surely within his rights to fiddle with the rate of duty
fields.body:
"The pips are squeaking and we must surely now be given some stability to continue to support our employment and tax base while delivering for shareholders." So said Ladbrokes as George Osborne increased duty on fixed-odds betting terminals (FOBTs), aka electronic roulette wheels. The rate will increase from 20% to 25% from March next year.

Let's sidestep the thorny issue of whether these machines deserve a place on the high street (this column's view: casino games belong in casinos) and address three questions raised by Ladbrokes' grumble.

First the plea for "some stability". Well, we'd all like that. But, come on, the Labour administration in 2001 that let bookmakers install four machines per shop didn't appreciate its own generosity. Last year the 8,874 machines in Ladbrokes shops each produced an average gross win of £915 a week – so a total of £442m for the company.

Remember, there is no bookmaking risk for the operator of these machines: the odds in roulette are fixed. Never has a piece of legislation been so lucrative for the industry. Whatever one's view of the machines themselves, a cash-strapped chancellor is surely within his rights to fiddle with the rate of duty.

Second, it's a bit rich for Ladbrokes to talk about "delivering for our shareholders". The prime reason why a hit of £20m or so from the duty change is so painful for Ladbrokes is that the company has been so slow to reinvent its core bookmaking business for the digital age. William Hill, Betfair and Paddy Power left Ladbrokes in the starting gate.

Third, it's tricky to argue that "the pips are squeaking" when you've just handed your chief executive, Richard Glynn, £4m in incentive shares. The value of that award has since fallen with the share price to about £2.5m – but that would not be everybody's definition of squeaking pips.

As it happens, the mainstream bookmaking industry has a decent argument that it is now being taxed at historically high rates. And the companies probably aren't exaggerating when they say some shops will have to close, implying job losses among the 40,000 people who work in the industry.

But it's disingenuous for Ladbrokes to portray itself as a helpless victim of a reckless chancellor making arbitrary tax changes. To borrow an Osborne pet phrase, the bookies had a chance to fix the roof when the sun was shining. The FOBT windfall, which was never going to last for ever on the same scale, created an opportunity to meet the online challenge. As the graphs show, some companies got their act together. William Hill, even after FOBT-related falls in its share price, has been a decent investment on a three-year view; Ladbrokes hasn't.

Bank of England modernisation

Despite the overdose of McKinseyite jargon, governor Mark Carney's "one mission, one bank" overhaul of the Bank of England looks a sensible piece of modernisation. There will now be four deputy governors, including Nemat Shafik from the International Monetary Fund. It sounds a lot but the Bank's powers and responsibilities have been massively extended.

The smartest reform was the creation of an oversight unit modelled on the independent evaluation office of the IMF. At the IMF, that unit has been refreshingly rude on occasions about the executives – it said "group think, intellectual capture and inadequate analytical approaches" caused the IMF to miss the global financial crisis.

But there's one oddity in the grand redesign. While Anthony Habgood is an excellent pick as the new chairman of the governing Court of the Bank – he has a long record of success at Bunzl, Whitbread and Reed Elsevier – why is the post only an eight-day-a-month gig?

If you are the chairman of Barclays, Lloyds or Royal Bank of Scotland you can't take another big job elsewhere. Your contract may say you are a part-timer but you are expected to drop everything if needs be. It would be impossible, for example, to be chairman of another FTSE 100 company.

Habgood, however, will continue to be chairman of Reed Elsevier, the £10bn publisher. He is a no-nonsense operator, so perhaps can get a lot done in two days a week. But it feels strange that chairing a big bank is regarded as more time-consuming than chairing the big Bank.

Trust trouble at Barclays

Why are the likes of Barclays struggling in their mission to "restore trust?" One reason is letters like the one received this week by Tim Gage, a chartered surveyor with a small practice in Essex. His business has been with Barclays since 1991 and he remembers when he could simply ring his bank manager to discuss his overdraft.

"Dear customer," begins Mr Suthern, Barclays' head of business banking, as a reminder that the days of the personal touch are long gone. He then details a 25% hike in interest rate margin from 7.99% to 9.99% over base rate. The explanation: "The cost of providing lending to customers is directly related to the requirement to set more capital aside to protect customers …"

That reads suspiciously like an attempt to point the finger at the Bank of England for jacking up capital requirements. But as our surveyor (who happens also to be a Barclays shareholder) knows, there were many contributors to Barclays' need for a £6bn rights issue last year. For example: Libor fines; compensation bills for misselling PPI and interest rate swaps; the risks in running an investment bank; sub-par returns from that same bonus-hungry investment bank. None of that is mentioned.

Barclays says the letter is part of its "business as usual" annual assessment of small business customers' overdrafts. It thinks our reader's business, based on past usage, will pay an extra £68 this year on a £2,500 facility. So it's not make-or-break territory.

More like extremely irritating, especially in a week when Barclays revealed it awarded £32m in shares to a dozen of its executives, including £3.8m for chief executive Antony Jenkins. Good luck with that trust thing, Mr Jenkins.

webTitle: US sanctions send Russian stock markets sliding

fields.standfirst:
• Russia’s Micex stock market falls 3.5% at open, RTS down 4.3%
  • Cameron warns Kremlin after 'Kalashnikov' referendum
  • Putin says won’t retaliate against US sanctions for now
  • Russia’s upper house approves annexation of Crimea
fields.body:
6.07pm GMT

Over to Greece where there is more drama on the horizon as parliament prepares to vote on an omnibus bill of reforms the country’s “troika” creditors have set as the price of aid. Helena Smith reports from Athens:

Prime minister Antonis Samaras’ fragile coalition has its work cut out for it in the days ahead after MPs in both the centre-right New Democracy Party and centre-left Pasok signaled they were not prepared to endorse certain measures in the all–encompassing bill of reforms.

A bill extending the shelf life of milk – part of a package of reforms demanded by lenders to boost competitiveness – has particularly rankled MPs. The deputy development minister Maximos Harakopoulos, a conservative, has said he would rather resign that support the bill expressing fears that it will hurt Greek dairy producers. At least three members of Pasok, the government’s junior partner, have voiced similar concerns. With the government’s parliamentary majority having shrunk to three in the 300-seat House – and the next €10. bn aid installment from the EU, ECB and IMF entirely dependent on the vote going through - insiders predicted there would be a lot of hand-wringing and “back-door meetings” aimed at persuading the lawmakers to change their stance. A meeting between Harakopoulos and one of Samaras’ top aides today showed no signs of breakthrough.

The sudden set back has put a dent in the euphoria expressed earlier by Samaras as he attended summit talks in Brussels. The Greek prime minister has been on a roll since the government clinched the deal – after seven months of often tortuous negotiations – telling Greeks that with the worst now behind them, the debt-stricken country was about to enter a new phase.

Leaving the talks Samaras told reporters: “It is both wrong and worrying for people that the day Greece opens its wings there are such disagreements.”

The opposition coincides with another day of intense protests in Athens with teachers being tear gassed by riot police as they stormed the offices of the administrative reform minister overnight.

And on that note, it's time to close up for the evening. Thanks for all your comments, and we'll be back again on Monday. Have a good weekend, all.

5.57pm GMT

The West needs to find a new form of deterrence as a reaction to the events in Ukraine, according to the Chatham House think tank. Associate fellow John Lough writes:

While a process has started, the impression remains that Western countries are playing catch up and that the strategic initiative still lies with Moscow. To turn this situation around, they need to decide in the short term whether in practice they genuinely intend to back Ukraine’s independence and prevent Russia from dictating the terms of its existence.

To do so, they need to assess the likelihood of Ukraine’s political leaders being able to pull together to lead the country out of crisis before they commit to support the process. Unfortunately, it is not a given that Ukraine’s politicians can catch up with society’s expectations to provide the leadership required.

Buying time for this purpose requires two immediate actions: firstly, delivering emergency financial resources to resuscitate to the economy and, secondly, creating space for Ukrainians to decide themselves how to govern their country...

Western countries need to force Moscow to make choices. This requires creating a new form of deterrence that targets its weaknesses. While Russia has competitive advantage over the West in Ukraine and across much of its periphery through the political, economic and military levers at its disposal, its stagnating economy is still based heavily on commodity exports and highly vulnerable to sustained economic pressure. To achieve traction with Russian decision-makers, the West needs to present a credible threat to inflict severe and lasting damage on the Russian economy.

Words matter. So far, the vocabulary of strategic deterrence is absent in discussions of how to manage the current crisis. If Western leaders want to influence Moscow’s behaviour, they need to find a linguistic register that moves beyond ‘sanctions’ and ‘possible targeted measures’ to express real strategic intent. The message to Moscow needs to spell out that the West defeated the USSR economically and is ready to adopt short-, medium- and long-term policies to undermine Russia’s economy if it continues to undermine Europe’s security.

The full commentary is here:

The West Needs a New Form of Deterrence that Targets Russia’s Weaknesses

5.28pm GMT

European markets close mainly higher despite Ukraine tensions

Investors are rightly nervous about the escalating tensions between the west and Russia following the annexation of Crimea, but for today at least markets seem to have taken a "wait and see" attitude to the situation. Talk of further Chinese stimulus measures to boost the economy provided some support, while Thursday's concerns about comments on US interest rates from new Federal Reserve chair Janet Yellen seemed short lived. So by the close of play:

• The FTSE 100 added 14.73 points or 0.23% to 6557.17

• Germany's Dax rose 0.5% to 9342.94

• France's Cac closed 0.17% higher at 4335.28

• Italy's FTSE MIB edged 0.58% lower to 20,972

• Spain's Ibex dipped 0.27% to 10,053

Russia's markets recovered much of their early falls, with Micex ending 1% lower and the dollar denominated RTS index down 1.27%.

On Wall Street the Dow Jones Industrial Average is currently 40 points or 0.,25% higher while at one point today the S&P 500 hit a new peak.

Updated at 5.37pm GMT

5.09pm GMT

There has been much talk about whether the European Central Bank would use quantitative easing, and governing council member Klaas Knot made it clear today that this would only be a last resort.

In an interview with Handelsblatt, as reported by Reuters, he said there were other measures which could be used first, even if there was a major deflationary spiral.

Updated at 5.09pm GMT

3.52pm GMT

EU adds twelve people to sanctions list

Twelve people have been added to the European Union sanctions list following the Kremlin's seizure of Crimea. They will have their assets in the EU seized and will be banned from travelling to the union.

They include Russian deputy prime minister Dmitry Rogozin and two aides to President Vladimir Putin, Vladislav Surkov and Sergey Glazyev.

The full list is here.

Updated at 3.54pm GMT

3.47pm GMT

Standard & Poor's has reaffirmed its B- rating on Greece with a sable outlook.

The rating is still seven notches below what is considered to be investment grade, but the agency said it believed the Greek economy was gradually rebalancing and it would grow over the next three years.

3.23pm GMT

Commenting on the confidence figures, Annalisa Piazza at Newedge Strategy said:

EMU consumer confidence has now reached a new relative high since late 2007, surpassing the relative peak registered in 2011.

Rising consumer confidence is welcome news as the EMU recovery is gaining steam only at a very modest pace and - at the current juncture - improving domestic demand is crucial for a more sustainable progress in activity.

In our view, today's outcome is mainly due to a combination of factors. First of all, the stabilization of the labour market across the major EMU economies (with a solid improvement in Germany); secondly, low inflation and low rates that help households' purchasing power and support the picture for major purchases in the future.

That said, low inflation could lead to some unwanted effects in the medium term and it remains a risk for the EMU economy as a whole. Should the current low inflation level affect inflation expectations, consumers might decide to postpone their spending plans and have a negative effects on domestic demand. As such, low inflation might turn to be negative should expectations of falling prices become entrenched. So far, such a scenario remains only a risk but we expect policymakers to continue to keep an eye on it.

3.15pm GMT

Eurozone consumer confidence better than expected

Away from Russia for the moment, and eurozone consumer confidence improved by more than expected in March.

Figures from the European Commission showed that the sentiment index jumped to -9.3 points, up from February's figure of -12.7 and better than the forecast -12.4.

In the European Union as a whole sentiment improved from -9.3 points in February to -6.7.

Updated at 3.23pm GMT

2.56pm GMT

With this, I am handing over to my colleague Nick Fletcher. Thankyou for all your comments and have a good weekend. JK

2.42pm GMT

Obama swapping his Blackberry for a Samsung?

Is Barack Obama swapping his (modified) BlackBerry for a Samsung? The BlackBerry has suffered another blow as the White House is testing smartphones from Samsung and LG, the Wall Street Journal reported. "We can confirm that the White House Communications Agency, consistent with the rest of the Department of Defense, is piloting and using a variety of mobile devices," a Defense Department spokesman told the paper.

A BlackBerry spokeswoman said:

For more than a decade, BlackBerry has been securing the U.S. government's mobile communications and only BlackBerry is designed to meet the high-security needs of U.S. and allied government agencies.

Updated at 2.46pm GMT

1.48pm GMT

In the meantime, the Russian foreign ministry hit back at US sanctions, saying in a statement:

We... will be tough in our response.

Washington should be under no illusions. The effectiveness of the sanctions in terms of American interests is zero. But the harm to US-Russian relations due to these irresponsible actions is inevitable.

1.43pm GMT

Cameron warns Kremlin after 'Kalashnikov' referendum

David Cameron warned the Kremlin that Russia would face “far reaching consequences in a broad range of economic areas” if it sent troops into eastern Ukraine after the “Kalashnikov” referendum in Crimea.

Since we last met a sham and illegal referendum has taken place at the barrel of a Kalshnikov and Russia has sought to annex Crimea. This is a flagrant breach of international law and something we will not recognise.

The best rebuke to Russia is a strong and successful Ukraine.

When asked whether Chelsea FC owner Roman Abramovich or other Russian tycoons should face sanctions, the British prime minister said:

We certainly haven’t ruled anyone out from this approach.

You need to target people who have a direct relationship with the action that’s been taken.

He also said Russia was more dependent on Europe than vice versa.

We should also remember that of course Europe is 25% or so reliant on Russian gas but if you look at Gazprom’s revenues something like 50% of them come from Europe... So Russia needs Europe more than Europe needs Russia.

Updated at 1.55pm GMT

1.33pm GMT

Wall Street opens higher

Wall Street has opened higher. The Dow Jones rose some 30 points or 0.2% while the S&P 500 added over 4 points or 0.2% in the first minute of trading. The FTSE 100 in London is 13.82 points ahead, the Dax in Frankfurt is up 17.37 points and the CAC in Paris has edged 4.28 points higher.

In Russia, the Micex is about 1% off while the dollar-denominated RTS has lost 1.4%. The rouble is down 0.4%.

Updated at 2.28pm GMT

1.28pm GMT

David Cameron is speaking. He says Russia needs Europe more than Europe needs Russia when it comes go gas.

Updated at 1.54pm GMT

12.19pm GMT

European markets keep 'calm and carry on'

Turning back to financial markets, Ishaq Siddiqi, market strategist at ETX Capital, said:

Equity markets in Europe adopt a calm mood Friday, helped by gains in Asian markets overnight. Ongoing geopolitical tensions in the Ukraine together with Fed chair Yellen’s remarks regarding monetary tightening keep us anxious in general but as we head to the end of the week, traders are demonstrating a level of comfort.

The Fed’s bank stress tests released overnight were better than expected, showing US banks are actually in much better shape than many had thought. Tougher sanctions by the US warrant some concern as President Obama noted that although these sanctions stand to hurt the Russian economy, these new stricter sanctions could eat away at global growth. Obama also imposed sanctions on Bank Rossiya, which the US government believe to be the personal bank for senior Russian officials – this led to Russia imposing sanctions on the US too. The escalation here is particularly worrying as rating agencies are now taking action. S&P cut Russia’s rating outlook to negative on Thursday followed by Fitch today. This prompted more than 3% drop for the Moscow stock index and further declines for the Rouble currency.

As a result, Russian bonds rose sharply as yields fell – Putin is currently signing the ratification of Crimea annexation – adding further fuel the fire in the political standoff between the West and Russia. The US is in a position to exert harsher sanctions but that’s not being replicated by the EU who have more to lose due to the closer trade links and reliance on Russia. So far, the EU’s sanctions have been incremental and perhaps not hard enough to hurt Russia’s growth prospects. That’s likely to be the case for some time with the US and Russia likely to be battling it out with the EU standing on the side of the ring, offering support to the US but ultimately, restrained to cause significant damage to Russia for the time being.

For financial markets at the moment, the Fed’s monetary tightening intentions appear to be a bigger deal – Fed chair Janet Yellen indicated the central bank could raise rates as early as April 2015, much earlier than expectations. Her comments shook investors who were resolute with the prospects of low interest rates for an extended period. Yellen however, was right to call for rate increases, if indeed, the US economic fundamentals justify monetary tightening.

12.14pm GMT

At an EU summit, there’s been discussion of stepping up efforts to reduce Europe’s reliance on Russian gas and oil. The EU has made some progress on improving its energy security after gas crises in 2006 and 2009 when rows over unpaid gas bills between Kiev and Moscow led to the disruption of supplies to western Europe. But Russia still provides about a third of the EU’s oil and gas – and some 40% of the gas is shipped through Ukraine.

European leaders are expected to call on the European Commission to draw up detailed proposals by June on how to diversify away from Russia. Europe has increased the share of renewable energy to around 15% and improved infrastructure.

Updated at 12.16pm GMT

11.35am GMT

Updated at 11.38am GMT

11.23am GMT

Market round-up

European markets have shrugged off the escalating Ukraine crisis ahead of the Wall Street open. London’s FTSE 100 index is trading some 24 points higher at 6567.04, a 0.37% gain. Germany’s Dax is nearly 50 points ahead, or 0.5%, at 9344.28, while France’s CAC has added over 15 points, or 0.37%, to 4343.96.

Russian stock markets have been hit after the US slapped fresh sanctions on Russian officials and Bank Rossiya, which has close links to Kremlin figures. The Micex and the dollar-denominated RTS index have recouped some of their earlier losses and are now down more than 2%. The rouble fell half a percent and Russia’s debt insurance costs rose slightly.

Toby Morris, senior sales trader at CMC Markets said:

The European warm up session has seen equities move higher, with the FTSE largely ignoring a slight miss from Public sector net borrowing, as well as another bad day for Russia’s benchmark index after increased sanctions from both the US and EU. For now the effects seem to be limited to stocks with specific Russian exposure, allowing the rest of the index to push on with the overall market move.

11.09am GMT

Footage has emerged from an attack on Ukraine’s state TV channel’s chief by a group of men attempting to force him to resign.

10.44am GMT

Over in China, business confidence dipped in the first quarter from a year ago, a central bank survey showed today, another sign that the Chinese economy is losing steam. The People’s Bank of China said the index measuring confidence among entrepreneurs dropped by 1 percentage point to 67%. The survey also showed that a growing number of Chinese banks are feeling the drag from the economic slowdown.

10.38am GMT

Former BOE official says Bank of England's trust in banks 'badly mistaken'

Former Bank of England policymaker Adam Posen says the central bank needs to abandon a culture of cosy chats and has been too trusting of banks. The Bank’s governor Mark Carney unveiled a major shake-up at the top earlier this week, following criticism that the central bank had been too slow to spot signs of financial misconduct.

Posen, who served on the monetary policy committee from 2009 until 2012, said the Bank’s staff had too much confidence that banks would regulate themselves and root out bad behaviour amongst their traders.

Posen told the BBC in a radio interview:

What is really most important is to see the Bank of England get away from being so trusting of the banks. That was the culture for a long time. It was not corrupt, it was just badly mistaken.

The Bank suspended an official earlier this month as part of an investigation into whether it had turned a blind eye to the alleged rigging of exchange rates.

Updated at 10.51am GMT

10.19am GMT

Here’s some reaction to the escalating standoff between Russia and the west.

Updated at 10.20am GMT

10.06am GMT

EU and Ukraine sign landmark association agreement, Russian parliament approves annexation of Crimea

The EU has signed a landmark association agreement with Ukraine. Ukrainian prime minister Arseny Yatseniuk, EU leaders Herman Van Rompuy and Jose Manuel Barroso and the heads of the EU’s 28 nations signed the core chapters of the Association Agreement on the sidelines of an EU summit in Brussels.

The deal commits the EU and Ukraine – with a population of 46 million – to closer political and economic cooperation, although the more important parts of the agreement relating to free trade will only be signed off after Ukraine has held new presidential elections in May.

In the meantime, Russia’s upper parliamentary chamber has approved a treaty signed by Putin to annex Crimea.

Updated at 11.27am GMT

9.54am GMT

The war of words continues. Russia’s prime minister Dmitry Medvedev said Ukraine owes Russia $16bn. He claimed Ukraine owes Russia $11bn because the treaty under which Russia provides Ukraine with cheap gas in return for the Sevastopol naval base was “subject to denunciation”. On top of that, Ukraine owes Russia $3bn for a recent loan and another $2bn to Gazprom, the Russian state-controlled gas giant.

Updated at 9.59am GMT

9.40am GMT

UK government borrowing lower in financial year so far

The UK public finance figures are out. They show the government’s financial position improved last month. The deficit was £9.3bn, according to the Office for National Statistics, taking cumulative borrowing for the financial year so far to 99.3bn – 4.3% lower than at this stage last year. With just one month left to go, this puts the chancellor on course to meet his new full-year borrowing forecast of £108bn – or 6.6% of GDP.

Departmental spending rose more than 7% in the 11 months to February, driven by new data on spending from the Department of Health. But there was also a big rise in “other receipts”.

Public sector net debt amounted to £1.2tn in February, equivalent to 74.7% of GDP.

Updated at 9.44am GMT

9.29am GMT

European companies with Russian exposure

Reuters has published a list of European companies with Russian exposure. In the FTSE 100, it lists Coca-Cola Hellenic Bottling (with 32% exposure), British American Tobacco, catering company Compass and packaging group Rexam.

Let’s look at the impact of the escalating standoff between the west and Moscow over Ukraine on western companies. Germany’s main trade body warned of disastrous consequences for the country’s 6,200 companies that do business with Russia. Anton Börner, head of the BGA exporters’ body, told regional newspaper Dortmunder Ruhr Nachrichten:

About 6,200 German companies are engaged in Russia, some of them very strongly. For them, economic sanctions would be a real catastrophe.

Börner said energy prices would rise if the crisis continues, but thought that Moscow was unlikely to cut off its energy supply completely to Germany. Germany relies on Russia for more than 30% of its oil and gas.

Germany’s “wise men” council of economic advisers said yesterday the Ukraine crisis was the biggest threat to global growth, and Germany in particular.

9.05am GMT

Putin says Russia won't retaliate against US sanctions for now

9.00am GMT

Russian deputy finance minister sees 'no severe consequences for the financial sector'

At the same time, Russian deputy finance minister Alexei Moiseev said he saw no big immediate impact from western sanctions on Russia’s financial sector and argued that the country’s creditworthiness had not worsened – hitting back after ratings agencies Fitch and Standard & Poor’s announced that they were changing the credit outlook on Russia to negative from stable. Moiseev said this morning:

For now, I see no severe consequences for the financial sector.

8.55am GMT

Russia threatens 'mirror response' to sanctions

8.49am GMT

Another Russian bank, SMP, whose main shareholders were hit by US sanctions, said Visa and MasterCard had stopped providing payment services. Washington imposed new sanctions last night against 20 Russians for their involvement in the Ukraine crisis, including Boris Rotenberg and his older brother Arkady, who bagged large contracts for the Sochi Winter Olympics. They are co-owners of SMB Bank.

8.36am GMT

Russian foreign ministry says sanctions are "unlawful" and create barriers

The Russian foreign ministry has angrily responded to the extension of international sanctions imposed on Russian officials and businessmen over the Crimea crisis.

Foreign minister Sergei Lavrov said the sanctions were “absolutely unlawful” and would create artificial barriers with the west. The comments came as he gave a speech in the upper house of parliament in which he urged the chamber to approve a treaty signed by Putin to make Ukraine’s Crimea region part of Russia.

The statement said:

Timchenko activities in the energy sector have been directly linked to Putin. Putin has investments in Gunvor and may have access to Gunvor funds.

Gunvor said the statement was “outrageous” and “blatantly false.”

8.10am GMT

With markets closed in Japan for the Spring Equinox national holiday, and no data due from the US, the economic focus today will be on Europe.

Economists at Daiwa Capital Markets Europe have done a helpful preview of today’s numbers.

Having taken a modest step back in February, the headline index is expected to increase by around 0.4pt on the month to -12.3, to leave the average for the quarter as a whole up more than 2pts compared with Q4 and close to the long-run average, therefore pointing to ongoing recovery in private consumption in the current quarter. Meanwhile, the latest balance of payments data are expected to show that the current account surplus remained near its historical high at the start of 2014.

Meanwhile, in the UK, the end of the week brings the latest public finance figures, which are expected to show that public sector net borrowing increased by £8bn in February, taking the cumulative borrowing in the year to date to a little less than £99bn, and therefore unsurprisingly consistent with the OBR’s estimate earlier in the week that the government will likely succeed in reducing its borrowing for the current fiscal year as a whole by around £7bn to £107.8bn.

Good morning, and welcome to our rolling coverage of the financial markets, the world economy, the eurozone and business.

New Fed chief Janet Yellen caught markets on the hop when she indicated that the first hike could come as early as March 2015. Michael Hewson, chief market analyst at CMC Markets UK, says we are set for a flat to slightly higher European open as we head into the weekend.

The only data of note is the latest UK public finances figures for February. The deficit is expected to return to the tune of £8bn.

Dallas Fed President Richard Fisher due to speak in London later this evening, followed soon after in Washington by dissenter Minneapolis Fed President Naryan Kocherlakota as well as Jeremy Stein, also both voting members of the FOMC.

To turn this situation around, they need to decide in the short term whether in practice they genuinely intend to back Ukraine’s independence and prevent Russia from dictating the terms of its existence. To do so, they need to assess the likelihood of Ukraine’s political leaders being able to pull together to lead the country out of crisis before they commit to support the process. Unfortunately, it is not a given that Ukraine’s politicians can catch up with society’s expectations to provide the leadership required. Buying time for this purpose requires two immediate actions: firstly, delivering emergency financial resources to resuscitate to the economy and, secondly, creating space for Ukrainians to decide themselves how to govern their country... webTitle: FTSE breaks three week losing streak as miners recover, but insurers suffer

fields.standfirst: Hopes of new Chinese measures lift commodity companies after recent falls
fields.body:
The FTSE 100 broke a three week losing streak despite growing tensions between the west and Russia over Ukraine, uncertainty about the Chinese economy and confusion about the US Federal Reserve's interest rate plans.

And George Osborne's latest budget also played its part in what was another volatile week, with insurers in particularly badly hit by the chancellor's surprise announcement that pensioners would no longer be forced to buy an annuity when they retired.

The news sent shares in annuity providers sharply lower on Wednesday, the day of the budget, and there was little recovery in the days following. Not surprising, perhaps, given that Barclays Equity Research summed up the change by saying it had "the potential to lead to the demise of the UK individual annuity market."

Legal and General was typical, down 7.1p on Friday to 206p taking its fall since the budget to 25p or nearly 11%.

Aviva fell 13.4p to 480.3p, down more than 37p since the announcement, while Prudential was 11p lower at £13.38. Analyst Eamonn Flanagan at Shore Capital said:

We estimate that the proportion of operating profits...emanating from UK individual annuities ranges from around 3% for Prudential to 7% for Aviva and Resolution and 8% for Legals.

Prudential was additionally hit by negative comments from Andy Hughes at Exane BNP Paribas. Hughes said the US had been the driving force behind the insurer's growth despite the attention given to its Asian businesses but said:

We remain underweight as we believe the share price overvalues the US-led earnings growth.

Resolution slipped another 0.9p to 317.2p despite Barclays' analysts raising their target price from 361p to 370p with an overweight rating, just a day after cutting the target from 378p to 361p in the immediate wake of the budget. Analysts Alan Devlin and Chris Roberts said:

We hosted Andy Briggs, chief executive of Resolution, in our London offices last night and found him to be relatively upbeat about Resolution's ability to deal with the biggest change the pensions industry has ever faced.
The chief executive had clearly thought through how the changes would affect the opportunity Resolution has in the retirement market. The key takeaway for us was that 1 in 9 UK pensions mature with Resolution, and that if the opportunity is not there to convert them into annuitants, they will still need another retirement product and Resolution will be in a strong position to provide that solution. The end product might change, the strategy does not. We believe the share price reaction, down 10% from Tuesday's close and 17% from its high earlier this month, is overdone and that at a 6.7% yield the stock is attractive at these levels.

Another annuity provider Partnership lost 1.8p on Friday to 122.2p while Just Retirement dropped 5.25p to 140p on news Schroders had sold 4.5m shares on Wednesday.

Bookmakers were the other big budget losers, as the chancellor raised the tax level on fixed odds betting machines from 20% to 25%. William Hill fell another 7.5p to 339.1p, while Ladbrokes lost 3.1p to 131p.

Overall the FTSE 100 finished at 6557.17 on Friday, up 14.73 points on the day and 29.28 points on the week, breaking a three week losing streak. Investors seemed to shrug off the escalating row over Ukraine and the growing number of sanctions against Russia, despite the uncertainty provoked by president Vladimir Putin's move on Crimea.

Further signs of a slowdown in China led to talk that the government could introduce new measures to stimulate the economy, including lifting funding restrictions for property developers and speeding up construction projects.

So mining shares were in demand after falls earlier in the week, with Anglo American adding 28p to 1439.5p, Fresnillo 18.5p better at 885p and Rio Tinto rising 50p to £32.07.

In the US, new Federal Reserve chair Janet Yellen caused a stir by seeming to suggest interest rates could rise within six months of the end of its monthly bond buying programme. But after an initial fall on Wall Street, analysts decided the Fed would only move if there were signs the US economy was running out of control, which did not seem likely, and markets recovered.

Elsewhere Burberry dropped 30p to £13.90 after Bank of America Merrill Lynch moved its rating on the business from buy to neutral. Analysts at the bank - one of Burberry's own brokers - said:

After adjusting our forecasts for the current foreign exchange headwind, Burberry would trade on ... a 6%-20% premium to luxury sector peers despite a lower forecast earnings growth profile. In our view, this premium valuation will limit outperformance in the near term.

webTitle: Regulators may launch investigation into big six energy companies next week

fields.bodyText: The big six gas and electricity suppliers are steeling themselves for a full competition inquiry beginning next week, against a background of accusations that the companies have used their market dominance to ramp up prices and make excessive profits. The financial, energy and consumer regulators have spent the last three months reviewing the workings of the market and are expected to publish a final report on Thursday. The Competition and Markets Authority (CMA), which has been working on the government-commissioned report with industry watchdog Ofgem and the Office of Fair Trading, will provide the latest detailed information on market share, relationships with customers and profit levels in different parts of the business. The report is intended to be a first annual study but is weighted with particular significance and could recommend no change, specific reforms or a fuller investigation by the CMA – which was created by the coalition to replace the Competition Commission as the lead competition body. Westminster insiders said there was intense pressure from the government on the regulators for a full competition inquiry, which could take 18 months to complete. "Ministers would love the whole public and political row over power prices to be kicked into the long grass until after the next general election," said one source. A senior industry insider told the Guardian: "We do not know for sure what the report will say but it is fair to say we expect an inquiry due to the political pressure." David Cameron announced the review in October in order to "get to the bottom of whether this market can be made more competitive." As recently as last month, Ed Davey, the energy and climate change secretary, kept up the pressure by writing to Ofgem to highlight the dominance of British Gas in the market. The row over high power prices, which has been simmering for years, took off last autumn when Ed Miliband told the Labour party conference that his government would freeze energy prices for 20 months from 2015 if Labour won the election. The opposition leader said Ofgem would be abolished and the large power companies broken up when the anger against energy companies escalated as household fuel prices were increased by around 10% in November. Soon after Miliband's intervention, Cameron announced his promise of an annual energy competition review, with next week's report representing its debut. Ofgem declined to comment on when the three regulators might publish their report or what it might say, but it has always argued that it remains strictly independent and stands apart from the political process. The regulator knows that it will come under attack if it does not deliver a full inquiry given the unease about accusations of profiteering and rising fuel poverty in Britain. Consumer group Which? has called for a deeper investigation after revealing that there were 5.5m complaints by big six customers last year alone. Even Tony Cocker, chief executive of E.ON UK, one of the big six, has written to the prime minister, secretary of state and Ofgem to call for a full Competition Commission inquiry. He told MPs that he hoped this would "depoliticise" a debate that energy bosses say is destroying investor confidence in the British market. Power companies have repeatedly claimed that their industry is being used as a political football, but critics insist the problems are self-inflicted and point to a series of multimillion pound fines for mis-selling, which have been announced at the same time as news of rising profits. There have also been rows about low tax payments and a failure to hand over excess cash balances. Citizens Advice claimed that gas and electricity prices had risen by up to eight times more than increases in average weekly earnings. The charity projected last November that by January of this year the big six suppliers would have raised their prices by 37% since October 2010. The average annual dual-fuel bill – for gas and electricity – is £1,315 per household. In fact prices have fallen slightly as the government has taken steps to lift the cost of various energy efficiency and other "green" measures from bills. The chancellor's budget on Wednesday froze planned increases in the carbon floor price that was meant to be used to drive out dirtier fossil fuels in favour of those that emit low levels of or noCO2.

webTitle: Royal Mail rises as HSBC puts £7bn valuation on the business

fields.standfirst: Analysts point to strong cashflow and dividend hopes, despite growing competition
fields.body:
Royal Mail is in demand after a positive note from HSBC.

The bank has begun coverage of the postal service with an overweight rating and 710p price target, valuing the business at more than £7bn. There was of course, some controversy over the valuation of the company when the government sold shares last October at 330p, with claims the price was set too cheaply.

This latest optimism from the City has seen the shares add 3.5p to 578.5p. The HSBC analysts said:

The Royal Mail Group has come a long way in terms of its modernisation programme. Most of the big step changes have been made but ongoing investment in improving IT and potential investment in new parcels sorting equipment as well as productivity improvements should help the company to stave off cost base inflation. Mail volumes are declining 4-6% per annum but pricing flexibility alongside decent parcels growth of around 5% in 2015-16 is able to compensate for this. This means Royal Mail can still deliver revenue growth of around 2% per annum.
Modernisation costs are declining and with the legacy pension deficit offloaded, Royal Mail is generating substantial cashflow. It has committed to paying a £200m annualised dividend for 2014 which represents a 3.4% yield. But with a free cash flow yield of 6% in 2014, rising to 7.2% in 2015 this is around twice covered and there is significant scope for increase. The balance sheet is not highly leveraged and upside could come from property disposals. End-to-end competition is a potential threat: TNT Post UK, which accounts for 20% of volumes for the Royal Mail, is gradually rolling out an end-to-end network. We believe that TNT's current end-to-end ambitions extend to around 6% of Royal Mail's volumes but in response Royal Mail has changed its access pricing to try to thwart cherry picking of the more densely populated areas. TNT has lodged a complaint and Ofcom is investigating. It remains unclear how Ofcom will deal with this and what action it will take if end-to-end competition does hurt the profitability of the Royal Mail. We see the strong cash flow generation as the key attraction of the Royal Mail and added to this potential upside from property disposals. Aside from the emergence of end-to-end competition, the key downside risk is higher-than-expected mail declines, as in the short term the cost base is sticky.

webTitle: Royal Bank of Scotland drops after court ruling and downgrade

fields.standfirst: Businessman allowed to start action against bank over alleged mis-selling
fields.body:
Royal Bank of Scotland is leading the FTSE 100 fallers following news of a legal judgement, as well as a broker downgrade.

A court ruled on Thursday that a businessmen could pursue the bank for alleged mis-selling of interest rate hedges. Alastair McCaig, market analyst at IG, said:

A fresh Pandora 's Box could have just opened for RBS, with the first of possibly many clients being allowed to sue the company over the mis-selling of interest-rate swaps.

Meanwhile Barclays has cut its rating on RBS from overweight to equal weight and its target price from 370p to 300p. Analyst Rohith Chandra-Rajan said:

RBS recently announced substantial revisions to its strategy to make it more UK retail and commercial banking focused with a materially smaller balance sheet and a much reduced cost base. Although a double digit return on tangible equity is feasible, it is highly dependent on the successful execution of an ambitious cost reduction plan and is unlikely to be achieved before 2017. With restructuring costs and other non operating charges likely to be significant we do not see tangible book value rising above its end 2013 level until 2016.
We believe that near-term pressure on tangible book value and a slow build in returns will weigh on share price performance and we downgrade our rating to equal weight with a reduced price target of 300p and see risks skewed to the downside. We prefer Lloyds Banking Group for exposure to a UK recovery which could drive a 20% earnings compound annual growth rate over the next three years.

RBS is currently down 6.8p at 298.5p, while Lloyds is 0.56p lower at 78.19p.

webTitle: Government borrowing edges up in February

fields.bodyText: A rise in local authority borrowing pushed up the government deficit by £9.3bn last month, but left George Osborne's deficit reduction plan on track, according to official figures. The Office for National Statistics said that for the first 11 months of the 2013/14 financial year borrowing was down £4.4bn on the same months last year to £99.3bn. Coming days after the chancellor said the public finances would be in surplus by 2018-19, the latest monthly data showed the Treasury remains on course to hit its borrowing target of £107.8bn when the financial year ends in April. Osborne said better than expected growth in the next couple of years would close the public spending deficit – the difference between tax income and government spending – at a faster rate than predicted last year. Howard Archer, chief UK economist at IHS Global Insight, said the figures represented mixed news for George Osborne. He said the underlying improvement in February was undermined by comparison with February 2013, when the shortfall was limited by a £2.3bn transfer from the sale of 4G mobile phone licences. "To meet his revised PSNBR [public sector net borrowing requirement] target of £107.8bn in 2013-14, the chancellor now needs the shortfall to come in at £8.5bn in March. This may prove difficult to achieve, given that there was a deficit of £11.4bn in March 2013," he said." webTitle: Meggitt moves higher after buy recommendation

fields.standfirst: Aircraft parts maker upgraded by UBS on prospects for commercial and energy sectors
fields.body:
As the FTSE 100 continues to shrug off the tensions between the west and Russia, one of the main risers is industrial group Meggitt.

The aircraft parts maker is up 7.2p to 476.7p after UBS raised its rating from neutral to buy. The bank edged down its 2014 earnings forecasts by 1%, saying it had been too enthusiastic about the prospects for margin recovery in the sensing systems business. This has led to UBS edging down its price target from 530p to 520p, but it said:

Meggitt is down 11% relative the FTSE 100 since mid-February, despite only a circa 2% EBITA and 4% earnings per share...downgrade [driven by foreign exchange]. The stock is now trading at the bottom of the range of its commercial peers (both original equipment and aftermarket oriented, but especially versus its aftermarket peers), which we believe is overdone on both relative and absolute basis and the stock offers good value at these levels.
We believe that Meggitt can sustain around 6% long term profit growth, driven mainly by the commercial aftermarket (largely planes that have already been sold) and the high growth energy sector (where Meggitt's proprietary technology gives them a performance advantage).

webTitle: Resolution recovers after budget falls and FTSE edges higher despite Russia sanctions

fields.standfirst: Investors remain cautious as tensions over Ukraine grow and sanctions imposed
fields.body:
One of the insurers hit by the changes to annuities announced in Wednesday's budget, Resolution, has been revived by a broker upgrade.

The company - which this week also said its restructuring was complete, its founders were leaving and it would be renamed Friends Life - is 8.7p higher at 326.8p, making it the biggest riser in the FTSE 100.

The move came as Barclays' analysts raised their target price from 361p to 370p with an overweight rating, just a day after cutting the target from 378p to 361p in the immediate wake of the budget. Analysts Alan Devlin and Chris Roberts said:

We hosted Andy Briggs, chief executive of Resolution, in our London offices last night and found him to be relatively upbeat about Resolution's ability to deal with the biggest change the pensions industry has ever faced.
The chief executive had clearly thought through how the changes would affect the opportunity Resolution has in the retirement market. The key takeaway for us was that 1 in 9 UK pensions mature with Resolution, and that if the opportunity is not there to convert them into annuitants, they will still need another retirement product and Resolution will be in a strong position to provide that solution. The end product might change, the strategy does not. We believe the share price reaction, down 10% from Tuesday's close and 17% from its high earlier this month, is overdone and that at a 6.7% yield the stock is attractive at these levels.

Other insurers however were under pressure again, with Aviva down 0.8p at 492.9p and Legal and General 0.4p lower at 212.7p.

Overall the FTSE 100 has edged higher after two days of losses. The index is up 19.18 points at 6561.62, shrugging off the growing tensions between Russia and the west over Ukraine, with a growing list of sanctions, as well as comments from new US Federal Reserve chair Janet Yellen on Wednesday suggesting interest rate rises could come within six months. Mike McCudden, head of derivatives at Interactive Investor, said:

There is a mild resurgence in confidence as we close out the week with the bounce in Asian markets enticing some investors out of the shadows. They will however need to remain fairly vigilant and nimble as the geopolitical and economic situation swings hot and cold on a daily basis. Indeed, dips in the FTSE 100 towards the 6500 level is enticing a wave of short term speculators each time.

Burberry is down 28p at £13.92 after HSBC reduced its price target from £18.50 to £18.20. Meanwhile Bank of America Merrill Lynch moved its rating on the business from buy to neutral.

But miners moved higher despite volatility in the copper price on concerns about a slowdown in the Chinese economy and worries about further Chinese corporate bond defaults.

Anglo American has added 30p to 1441.5p while Mexican precious metals miner Fresnillo is up 17p at 883.5p as gold and silver prices edge higher as safe havens in the current uncertainty.

webTitle: Carpet, bed and sofa retailers promise 'genuine prices' after OFT investigation

fields.standfirst: Carpetright, Dreams, Furniture Village, Harveys, Bensons for Beds and ScS accept Office for Fair Trading demands on promotional pricing
fields.body:
Carpetright and four other flooring and furniture retailers have promised to clean up their pricing after reaching a settlement with the Office of Fair Trading.

The OFT said the store groups had changed the way they advertise goods that they claim have been reduced.

The watchdog's investigation last year found widespread misuse of promotions. Offers advertised for a limited period, often over bank holidays, were used to pressurise shoppers into making instant purchases. But the OFT found that just 5% of products were ever sold at the higher advertised price and many were never sold at that price.

The settlement covers Carpetright, bed retailer Dreams, Furniture Village, Homestyle's Harveys and Bensons for Beds chains, and sofa specialist ScS. DFS, which was part of the same investigation, was cleared by the OFT in December.

The OFT said a pre-discount price was highly unlikely to be genuine and fair if it was only available in a few stores, or if the discounted price was in effect the normal price.

Without accepting liability, the retailers have pledged to show prices that reflect genuine discounts.

Gaucho Rasmussen, head of the OFT's goods and consumer group, said: "Retailers advertise bargains and discounts by referring to a previous or future higher price. It's a powerful marketing tool which, when used properly, provides a helpful and easy way to demonstrate to shoppers the value of discounts and savings. We are therefore pleased that these retailers have confirmed their commitment to using genuine prices."

Lord Harris of Peckham, Carpetright's executive chairman, claimed the OFT was "completely satisfied" that his company complies with its requirements.

"We are pleased the OFT has publicly welcomed Carpetright's commitment to open and transparent pricing," Harris said.

The OFT warned it would continue to monitor retailers in the sector to make sure they kept their promise.

Alex Chisolm, chief executive of the Competition and Markets Authority, which takes over from the OFT next month, said: "Companies are advised to satisfy themselves that their practices are in line with the law because failure to do so could risk enforcement action."

Shares in Carpetright, which issued a profit warning in January, were down 0.9% at 589.5p in early trading.

webTitle: Gina Rinehart secures funding to operate her own iron ore mine

fields.standfirst: Hancock Prospecting signs US$7.2bn funding packing for Roy Hill project in the Pilbara
fields.body:
Australia’s richest person, Gina Rinehart, will become the world’s fifth-largest iron ore producer after securing the money to operate her own mine.

Rinehart’s company Hancock Prospecting signed a US$7.2bn (A$7.98bn) funding package for the US$10bn Pilbara mine and railway in Singapore on Thursday. The Roy Hill iron ore mine will be more than 70% debt funded.

The move comes more than 60 years after Rinehart’s father, Lang Hancock, discovered the world’s largest iron ore deposit in Western Australia’s Pilbara.

Roy Hill’s chief executive, Barry Fitzgerald, said the funding package was the biggest of its kind in the world.

The funding from an international consortium of 19 banks, including Australia’s big four lenders, is a vote of confidence in the mine despite falling iron ore prices and warnings of oversupply and less demand out of China.

The mine is due to start exporting next year and when it ramps up to 55m tonnes a year it will be the world’s fifth-biggest producer behind Andrew Forrest’s Fortescue Metals.

Rinehart described the project as a “crucible of opportunity during a period of global uncertainty”.

There are 2,500 people working on building the project, to rise to 3,600 later this year, with 2000 permanent staff to be employed at the operating mine.

“It has already shown it will create new jobs and benefit the greater mining and construction-related industries,” Rinehart said. “It will add to Australia’s exports, and significantly benefit our West Australian and national economy.”

The mine will also enable Rinehart to operate a mine in her own right, with her near $20bn in current wealth attributable to her share of profits at the Rio Tinto-operated Hope Downs mine.

Some commodity analysts warn the iron ore market is becoming oversupplied, which will make it harder for Roy Hill to be profitable.

But senior resources analyst Gavin Wendt, a director of MineLife, disagrees, citing the quality of iron ore Roy Hill will produce. It is located in the same Pilbara region as the world’s iron ore giants BHP Billiton, Rio Tinto and Fortescue Metals.

It will also not be wholly dependent on China, counting Japan’s Marubeni and South Korea’s Posco as major shareholders and export credit agencies and banks from those countries will supply much of the funding.

Wendt pointed out that Japan and South Korea’s more-developed economies produced a higher quality steel than China and demanded the high-quality product Roy Hill would produce.

“They’ve always been the biggest customers historically for Pilbara iron ore,” he said. “China’s demand for Pilbara-blend high-quality iron ore is also going to probably grow as it cracks down on inefficient high polluters in its steel industry.

“It really is a triumph for her and good on her ... It is an important project, Roy Hill, as you don’t typically find high-quality premium iron ore projects in low political-risk destinations like Australia.”

webTitle: Rio Tinto chief urges carbon capture progress despite research funding halt

fields.standfirst: Mining executive says fossil fuels ‘here to stay’ and calls for cleaner technology yet industry research body starved of funds
fields.body:
A Rio Tinto executive has claimed it is “fruitless to keep indulging in idealistic discussions about climate change” because fossil fuels are “here to stay” and has demanded more investment in carbon capture and storage.

But the company, along with other Australian coal producers, has stopped payments to the industry’s much-vaunted Coal21 fund to help finance research on that technology.

In a speech to the Energy Policy Institute of Australia on Friday, Rio Tinto’s head of energy, Harry Kenyon-Slaney, said: “It is clear we can’t just wish away fossil fuels. Any solution to climate change must recognise the ongoing significant role of fossil fuels in the global energy mix. It would simply be impractical and unrealistic not to do so.

“Aside from the obvious need to encourage behavioural change to reduce energy wastage, I believe that the answer will come from technological advances and innovative solutions. Raising the efficiency of power stations from the lamentable average of 33% will be one key step and advancing carbon capture and storage will be another.”

He said Rio Tinto had spent more than $100m on “activities directed towards the development of carbon capture and storage technology”.

But along with other Australian black coal producers, Rio has also “paused”, from 2012-13, contributions to what was supposed to become a $1bn industry fund to finance clean coal technology “in response to difficult trading conditions in the industry”.

The objectives of Coal21, set up in 2006, have also been changed to allow it to use funding already collected for advocacy and promoting the use of coal.

Its constitution now allows money to be spent on “promoting the use of coal both within Australia and overseas and promoting the economic and social benefits of the coal industry”.

A spokesman for the Minerals Council of Australia said it was “axiomatic” that a healthy coal industry was necessary for more money to be spent on clean coal research.

He said no money from the fund was being spent on advocacy and promotion at the moment and it was unrelated to the global campaign by Peabody Energy – which has been prominent in many Australian news outlets – to promote fossil fuels as the answer to world “energy poverty”.

The “Advanced Energy for Life” campaign describes energy poverty as “the world’s No 1 human and environmental crisis”.

The interim chief executive of Australian Coal Association Low Emissions Technologies (ACALET), Greg Sullivan, said “despite difficult operating conditions, the Australian coal industry is continuing to in invest in low emissions technology development. There has been a pause in levy liabilities but ACALET has and continues to commit new money to projects.”

It is understood the new investments would come from funds already collected. It has cash reserves of about $26m.

Kenyon-Slaney applauded the government’s review of the 20% renewable energy target, headed by veteran businessman Dick Warburton, a self-professed climate sceptic.
